definitions.definition: used to say that something is necessary or very important (sometimes involving a rule or a law)

examples.text: All visitors must report to reception.
Cars must not be parked in front of the entrance *(= it is not allowed)*.
I must ask you not to do that again.
You mustn't say things like that.
I must go and get the kids from school.
**I must admit** *(= I feel that I should admit)* I was surprised it cost so little.
Must you always question everything I say? *(= it is annoying)*
‘Do we have to finish this today?’ ‘Yes, you must.’

definitions.definition: used to say that something is likely or logical
definitions.labels: North American EnglishBritish EnglishBritish EnglishNorth American EnglishBritish English(British English)

examples.text: You must be hungry after all that walking.
He must have known *(= surely he knew)* what she wanted.
I'm sorry, she's not here. She must have left already *(= that must be the explanation)*.

definitions.definition: used to recommend that somebody does something because you think it is a good idea

examples.text: You simply must read this book.
We must get together soon for lunch.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody may do something but you do not really want them to

examples.text: It's from my boyfriend, **if you must know**.

definitions.definition: used to tell people that something is so good or interesting that they should see, read, get it, etc.

examples.text: Sydney is one of the world's must-see cities.
The magazine is a must-read in the show business world.
This is on my must-do list.

definitions.definition: in certain situations it is necessary for you to do something that you do not like or enjoy

wordOrigin: Old English mōste, past tense of mōt ‘may’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch moeten and German müssen.
